text: Patient: And he’s said he’s had good luck with other patients that have had pain with that Cymbalta. Doctor: In the joints? I mean I don’t know how it will help with that with your pain, but you know what it’s definitely worth a try. I have no objections to giving that a try but I’m not terribly hopeful, but if he’s seen something different in his experience. Patient: Well if that’s the case I’ll just stay on the prednisone. Forget that. I mean it’s not something Doctor: Okay I mean I’m okay if you want to give that a try Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: and there’s no objection or problem - Patient: Okay. Doctor: from the study standpoint. Patient: Alright, Okay. Family Member: Which is the lesser of the two evils as far as taking it long term? I’m not familiar with Cymbalta. Doctor: Well, I think Cymbalta is probably you know much more proven you know long term. The steroids can have other issues of you know blocking the immune systems likely increased risk of infections and things like that over the long term, but you know it’s – I kind of think it’s unlikely that it will help arthritic pain. If it is neuropathic nerve pain and stuff, you know Cymbalta can be effective. Patient: Yeah I think that’s what he said also yeah. Doctor: I don’t think that is the reason for your pain, but that’s my impression.

text: Patient: No. Doctor: You didn’t notice any different? Doctor: Okay so should we try going to five once a day or you don’t want to rock the boat? Patient: I suppose we could try it and see what happens. Doctor: We’re gonna try it. Family Member: Or even five one day and two the next and five one day and two the next. Doctor: I was just gonna say or maybe do it every other day. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And see how you do. Patient: Yeah I can do that. Doctor: Because now if you’re not aggregating it with this medication… Patient: Oh yeah, yeah.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
